text: death it's something we try not to think
about but we should avoiding it means we
miss out on the chance to think more
deeply about how we really want to spend
our time imagine yourself lying there on
a hospital bed knowing your time's up
what could you have done differently
it's only by reflecting on how we might
look back over our lives as they come to
an end that we can make sure we don't
regret anything in the top five regrets
of the dying bronnie wear a nurse who
worked with hundreds of dying patients
shares her experiences listening to
people's Deathbed regrets so that we can
learn from them she writes if we're able
to face our own inevitable death with
honest acceptance before we have reached
that time then we shift our priorities
well before it's too late this gives us
the opportunity to then put our energies
into directions of True Value once we
acknowledge that limited time is
remaining although we don't know if that
is years weeks or hours we're less
driven by ego or by what other people
think of us instead we are more driven
by what our hearts truly want
this acknowledgement of our inevitable
approaching death offers us the
opportunity to find greater purpose and
satisfaction in the time we have
remaining by studying the most common
deathbed regrets of others we can avoid
the mistakes they made so let's dive in
regret number one I wish I had the
courage to live a life true to myself
not to the life others expected of me
bronnie had a patient named Grace
Grace's husband was abusive and
controlling he ruled over her she
dreamed of traveling and being free
Grace's husband eventually got sick and
she was excited to start doing what she
wanted but soon after she was diagnosed
with the serious illness herself and
couldn't get out of bed Grace was angry
and regretful that she lost so many
years of her life to an abuser she wish
she had been able to live life on her
own terms now this isn't a situation
thankfully that most of us will be able
to relate to but we all let other people
shape our lives in other ways every
single one of us worries what other
people think and in this way we let
other people control Our Lives humans
are social creatures we need other
people our lives depend on fitting in
and having others like us but on their
deathbeds people often realized that
they cared way too much about what other
people thought of them they stayed in
bad relationships because they worried
what their families would think if they
left they chose careers to impress
people not because they were passionate
about them they ignored the voice in
their head telling them that their lives
weren't right because making changes
seemed to too painful they went with the
flow and accepted mediocrity we make
excuses and put off starting to live a
life true to ourselves because we always
think we have more time but time often
runs out before we've had the chance you
see the secret is that most people are
way too busy with their own lives to
care about ours there's an old saying we
care so much about what others think of
us until we realize they never really do
when we're coming to the end of our
Lives we'll probably reflect on how
other people's opinions in society 's
expectations don't really matter so why
not let go and be yourself now regret
number two is I wish I hadn't worked so
hard in their final moments many of
Bron's patients told her that they
regretted prioritizing work above
everything else one of her patients kept
putting off retirement to spend time
with his family always wanting to save
just a bit more but right as he was
about to retire his wife got ill and
died leaving him with a bunch of money
but totally alone it's a common story we
work and work dreaming of a glorious
retirement but many of us never get
there Ronnie writes we spend so much
time making plans for the future
depending on things coming at a later
date to assure our happiness when all we
ever have is our life today even the
people lucky enough to get to retirement
healthy and with plenty of cash in the
bank have still exchanged young years
for old ones they might not even
physically be able to do many of the
things they planned when they were
spending their younger years grinding
away at work let's be real work is
obviously important and doing work we're
good at and find meaningful is a big
part of a good life the problem is
letting work take over your life become
your whole identity and push out
everything else friends family health
hobbies and travel remember that no
matter how great your colleagues are
they won't always be around they won't
save you in a crisis they won't comfort
you when you're sick they won't be with
you in your final days we take family
for granted but these are the
relationships people truly care about
when looking back on their lives don't
sacrifice them for more money or stuff
you don't need if what you have now
isn't enough having more probably won't
be either regret number three I wish I
had the courage to express my feelings
opening up and expressing our feelings
is hard being vulnerable leaves us open
to being hurt judged or ridiculed so we
build walls around ourselves keeping
people out children are really good at
expressing emotions but as adults
gradually the defenses go up we do this
to avoid the pain that comes with
honesty but the price we pay is living a
life without the people around us truly
knowing who we are patients often said
on their deathbeds that they wish they
hadn't been so afraid of being open and
honest they were sad that they reached
the end of their lives feeling like
people never really understood them they
were bitter and resentful we have a deep
need to feel connected to other humans
re shows that when we hold back hide or
ignore emotions it causes mental health
problems like anxiety as well as
physical health issues like immune
problems hiding emotions doesn't make
them go away it can actually make them
stronger as they grow each time we
ignore them however studies show that
being vulnerable benefits our lives in
so many ways people feel closer to us
and want to open up themselves creating
stronger connections they trust us more
and feel more comfortable around us if
talking about your deepest darkest
secrets seems like a lot right now start
small share something not too difficult
with a close friend or family member or
even write about your emotions in a
private journal the fourth regret is I
wish I had stayed in touch with my
friends tragically many people in
nursing homes are very lonely we think
our friends will always be there but we
get busy Our Lives get in the way and
before we know it connections go cold in
their Dying Days many people suddenly
find themselves without anyone in the
world who understands them closely or
knows anything about their history they
say they have deep regrets about losing
touch with friends as bronny says
everyone misses their friends when
they're dying social connections are
what make life worth living all the
money status and material possessions in
the world can't make up for a lack of
genuine friends research shows that the
quality of our social relationships and
how many friends we feel we can rely on
are the main things that determine how
healthy and happy we are loneliness can
make us physically sick friends make the
good times better and the hard hard
times easier it's easier to maintain
friendships than start them up again
once they've been lost so take action
now send a friend you haven't spoken to
for a while a message saying you're
thinking of them or schedule a hangout
and most importantly let them know you
value them in your life it's something
we all need to hear regret number five I
wish I'd let myself be happier many of
Bron's patients had the realization too
late that happiness is a choice we get
stuck in familiar habits and ways of
thinking that don't serve us us we
pretend to other people and even
ourselves that we're happy because we're
scared of what they'll think if we tell
them the truth part of the problem is
that we say to ourselves that it's okay
not to be happy or not to prioritize our
own happiness because it'll all work out
in the future we think it's fine to be
miserable today if we're sacrificing for
a better tomorrow and this isn't always
bad it's important to work towards our
goals and try to achieve big things but
we need to let ourselves be happy along
the way it's about the journey gratitude
for every day along the way is the key
to acknowledging and enjoying happiness
now not when the results come in or when
you retire or when this or that happens
the danger of putting off and letting
ourselves be happy is that the future
might never arrive life is hard even for
the luckiest people but tough times and
challenging circumstances shouldn't get
in the way of finding peace and
happiness in the present these are the
five most common regrets of the dying
according to bronny wear's book about
people in their Dying Days the top five
regrets of the dying talking about death
isn't easy but by studying what people
at the end of their lives wish they had
done differently we can make changes and
avoid living lives we'll regret before
it's too late I'll see you on the next
one
